channel.title: BBC News - World

item.title: Afghanistan: Biden says another Kabul airport attack likely
item.description: The US president says commanders have told him another attack could happen within the next 36 hours.

item.title: Victims' relatives still desperately search for news of loved ones
item.description: The BBC's Secunder Kermani reports on the human cost of the Kabul airport attack.

item.title: Robert F Kennedy assassin Sirhan Sirhan recommended for parole
item.description: A parole board calls for Sirhan Sirhan's release, but the decision now goes to California's governor.

item.title: French woman arrested over jewellery thefts from coffins
item.description: Police believe the woman was posing as a mourner to strip valuables from the recently deceased.

item.title: Canada election: Justin Trudeau rally cancelled after angry protests
item.description: Jeering crowds force the Canadian prime minister to call off an election campaign event.

item.title: Chinese firm probes ‘false’ anti-Uyghur job ads
item.description: Shein said it did not fund or approve adverts that suggested some ethnic minorities need not apply.

item.title: Hurricane Ida: New Orleans braces for possible direct hit
item.description: Hurricane Ida is forecast to strike as a category 4 storm, even stronger Katrina 16 years ago.

item.title: Greenland island is world's northernmost island - scientists
item.description: They say a tiny island off Greenland's coast was discovered by luck during a recent expedition.

item.title: Covid origin: US spy agencies publish 'inconclusive' report
item.description: The office that oversees US spy agencies could not establish how the coronavirus pandemic began.

item.title: Austrian ex-far-right leader Strache guilty of corruption
item.description: The verdict comes two years after a video sting ended Heinz-Christian Strache's political career.

item.title: Capitol riot: Officer who shot Ashli Babbitt reveals identity
item.description: Lt Michael Byrd told NBC that he believes he saved "countless lives" on 6 January.

item.title: Who are the group that attacked Kabul airport?
item.description: The local branch of Islamic State claimed responsibility for the Kabul’s airport attack, but what threat do they pose?

item.title: Week in pictures: 21 - 27 August 2021
item.description: A selection of powerful images from all over the globe, taken this week.

item.title: Sierra Leone's chimpanzees: The newly weds who set up a sanctuary
item.description: A couple who 30 years ago bought an abused chimpanzee are now trying to save a subspecies.

item.title: Covid-19: The Indian children who have forgotten how to read and write
item.description: Schools in India have been closed for more than a year, with learning outcomes falling drastically.

item.title: Afghans in Calais prepare to risk lives again to reach UK
item.description: Aid agencies on the French coast are preparing for a new influx of migrants trying to get to the UK.

item.title: Afghanistan's Uyghurs fear the Taliban, and now China too
item.description: Members of the ethnic group say they fear the Taliban takeover could bring China to their doorstep.

item.title: Strictly: Why are South African dancers so popular?
item.description: As Strictly prepares to return to our screens next month another South African dancer has joined the professionals.

item.title: Cows on the moo-ve from Swiss Alpine meadow
item.description: Some cows are carried by helicopter in a process used by farmers to move the injured ones.

item.title: ICYMI: Tank ballet, lederhosen and a brave swan
item.description: Stories you may have missed this week include Russian army games and a WWII bunker turned into a B&B.

item.title: Pakistan-Afghanistan border: Ambassador pressed over threat from terrorist groups
item.description: The BBC's Lyse Doucet spoke to Mansoor Ahmad Khan, Pakistan's ambassador to Afghanistan.

item.title: Kabul airport bomb attacks leave many casualties
item.description: Reports say at least 90 people were killed, with civilians and US military personnel among the dead.

item.title: Afghanistan interpreter: Getting plane out was 'happiest moment of my life'
item.description: Former Afghan interpreter Burhan and his family are now in the UK, after begging for help to escape.

item.title: Afghanistan: Shukria Barakzai's whispered voice notes and dramatic escape
item.description: The desperate messages sent by Afghan politician Shukria Barakzai to a UK MP. as the Taliban tried to hunt her down.

item.title: 'The Taliban killed my brother for protecting my family'
item.description: Saba says his family have gone into hiding after the Taliban threatened to kill his nephews.

item.title: Afghanistan: How do the Taliban make money?
item.description: The Taliban maintain a sophisticated financial network and taxation system to generate income.

item.title: Afghan music school falls silent under Taliban rule
item.description: As the new regime bans music, the head of Afghanistan's national music school says students are scared.

item.title: Afghanistan: How much opium is produced and what's the Taliban's record?
item.description: The Taliban claims opium poppy cultivation was stopped when it last held power in Afghanistan.
